Improve the first-run experience for new users. Currently users are confused by:
- Not knowing 2 API keys are needed upfront
- The 'no superconnect.toml' message looking like an error
- Opaque phrases like 'component repo path'
- Bracket syntax for defaults not being obvious

This epic addresses the complete onboarding flow from first command to successful run.

Improve the first-run experience for new users. Currently users are confused by: not knowing 2 API keys are needed upfront, the no superconnect.toml message looking like an error, opaque phrases like component repo path, bracket syntax for defaults not being obvious. This epic addresses the complete onboarding flow from first command to successful run.

## Problem
When users run via npx @bitovi/superconnect without installing, npm caches old versions and they dont get the latest.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Document the npx cache issue in README troubleshooting section
- Add --force flag recommendation: npx @bitovi/superconnect@latest or npx --yes @bitovi/superconnect
- Consider adding version check on startup that warns if newer version available

## Validation
- README has clear guidance for npx users
- Test: npx @bitovi/superconnect@latest fetches current version

## Problem
README only shows pnpm install commands. Many users use npm or yarn.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Installation section shows all package managers: npm, pnpm, yarn
- npx usage is documented with cache-busting tips
- Global vs local install options explained

## Validation
- README has npm install -g, pnpm add -g, yarn global add examples
- npx @bitovi/superconnect@latest documented

## Problem
Current api values in superconnect.toml are opaque:
- anthropic-agents (unclear what this means)
- anthropic (vs what?)
- openai (ok but inconsistent)

## Proposed New Values
- anthropic-agent-sdk (Claude Agent SDK with tool use)
- anthropic-messages-api (Anthropic Messages API, stateless)
- openai-chat-api (OpenAI Chat Completions API)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Rename api enum values in code
- Support old values as aliases with deprecation warning
- Update superconnect.toml comments to explain each option
- Update README and docs

## Validation
- Old configs still work with warning
- New configs use descriptive names
- Docs explain the difference between each option

## Problem
base_url in [agent] section is vague. Users dont know what URL goes here.

## Proposal
Rename to openai_base_url or custom_api_endpoint with better comments.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Rename base_url to openai_base_url (or custom_endpoint)
- Add inline comment explaining this is for LiteLLM, Azure, vLLM, LocalAI etc
- Support old key as alias with deprecation warning

## Validation
- Old configs still work
- New key name is self-documenting

## Problem
When superconnect.toml is missing, the output looks like an error. But this is expected on first run - its actually the setup flow.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Change the yellow warning styling to a friendly welcome message
- Something like: Welcome to Superconnect! Lets set up your project.
- Make it clear this is normal first-run behavior, not an error
- Keep the interactive prompts that follow

## Validation
- First run feels welcoming, not alarming
- Returning users with existing config see the normal Using superconnect.toml message

## Problem
When prompting like: Enter component repo path [.]: many users dont realize the bracketed value is the default if they press Enter.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Add explanatory text on first prompt: (press Enter to accept default in brackets)
- Or rephrase prompts to be explicit: Enter path, or press Enter for current directory (.)
- Be consistent across all prompts

## Validation
- Users understand they can press Enter to accept defaults
- No more confusion about bracket syntax

## Problem
The prompt component repo path is jargon. Users dont know what this means.

## Proposal
Rename to something like:
- Path to your component library
- Where are your React/Angular components?
- Project directory

## Acceptance Criteria
- Rename the prompt text to be more intuitive
- Update the TOML key and comments
- Support old key as alias

## Validation
- New users understand what to enter without guessing

## Problem
Users struggle to find and create Figma tokens and AI provider API keys. Text instructions arent enough.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Create or source animated gifs showing:
  1. How to create a Figma personal access token with correct scopes
  2. How to create an Anthropic API key
  3. How to create an OpenAI API key
- Embed gifs in README setup section
- Host gifs in repo or on reliable CDN

## Validation
- Visual learners can follow along
- Gifs are up to date with current UI

## Notes
May want to use a screen recording tool like Kap or LICEcap

## Goal
Restructure CLI so that setup (init) is clearly separate from execution (run).

## New Command Model
- superconnect init: Interactive setup wizard, creates/updates superconnect.toml
- superconnect: Run generation, requires valid toml (fails helpfully if missing)
- superconnect --init: Force re-run setup even if toml exists

## Key Principles
- Toml represents validated inputs ready to execute, not settings for re-runs
- First run should build confidence before spending money on LLM calls
- Detection and validation happen in init, not during generation
- Init can optionally proceed to run after confirmation

## Success Criteria
- Running superconnect without toml gives clear message pointing to superconnect init
- Init wizard gathers all required info with confirmation before writing toml
- Init shows summary of what will happen before asking to proceed
- Subsequent superconnect runs are fast (no re-prompting)

## Goal
Make superconnect work correctly in monorepos by properly detecting packages and resolving import paths.

## Problem
In monorepos, the tool currently:
- May scan from wrong root, finding too much or wrong components
- Generates wrong import paths (file paths instead of package names)
- Does not know which package is the design system vs consuming apps

## Solution
1. Detect monorepo (root package.json has workspaces)
2. Scan for nested package.jsons, build package map
3. Ask user which package contains the design system
4. Read that packages name field for import path
5. Scope component scanning to that package only
6. Pass package name to codegen for correct imports

## New Config Fields
- target_package: path to the package directory (e.g. packages/design-system)
- import_from: the npm package name (e.g. @corp/design-system) - can be auto-detected from package.json

## Success Criteria
- Monorepo users get correct import statements in generated Code Connect
- Init wizard detects monorepo and offers package picker
- Single-repo case continues to work as before
- Import paths use package names, not file paths

## Task
Add init subcommand that runs the interactive setup wizard.

## Implementation
- Add commander subcommand: superconnect init
- Move existing promptForConfig logic into init command
- Init should NOT automatically run generation afterward (separate step)
- Write superconnect.toml on completion

## Acceptance Criteria
- superconnect init runs the wizard
- Wizard creates superconnect.toml
- Does not run generation automatically

## Validation
- Run superconnect init in a fresh directory
- Verify toml is created
- Verify generation does NOT run

## Task
Change default superconnect command to require existing toml.

## Implementation
- If no superconnect.toml exists, print helpful message and exit
- Message should say: No superconnect.toml found. Run superconnect init to set up your project.
- Do not run interactive prompts from the main command
- Only run generation if toml exists and is valid

## Acceptance Criteria
- Running superconnect without toml shows helpful error
- Running superconnect with valid toml runs generation
- No interactive prompts in main command

## Validation
- Run superconnect in dir without toml - should fail with helpful message
- Run superconnect in dir with toml - should run generation

## Task
Add --init flag that forces the setup wizard to run even if toml exists.

## Implementation
- Add --init flag to main command
- If --init is passed, run init wizard regardless of toml presence
- Existing toml values should be used as defaults in prompts
- After wizard completes, optionally proceed to generation

## Acceptance Criteria
- superconnect --init runs wizard even with existing toml
- Existing values are shown as defaults
- User can update or keep existing values

## Validation
- Create toml with init
- Run superconnect --init
- Verify existing values shown as defaults
- Verify toml is updated with new values

## Task
Before running generation, show summary of what will happen and ask for confirmation.

## Implementation
- After loading toml but before generation, print summary:
  - Package/repo being scanned
  - Figma file being connected
  - Number of components found (if already scanned)
  - Estimated LLM calls
  - Output directory
- Ask: Proceed with generation? (Y/n)
- Allow --yes flag to skip confirmation

## Acceptance Criteria
- Summary shows before generation
- User must confirm (or use --yes)
- Summary includes key info about what will happen

## Validation
- Run superconnect with valid toml
- Verify summary appears
- Verify confirmation prompt works
- Verify --yes skips prompt

## Task
At end of init wizard, offer to proceed directly to generation.

## Implementation
- After writing toml, ask: Run generation now? (Y/n)
- If yes, run generation (with summary/confirmation from other task)
- If no, exit with message: Run superconnect when ready

## Acceptance Criteria
- Init offers to run after setup
- User can decline and run later
- If user proceeds, generation runs

## Validation
- Run superconnect init
- Say yes to proceed
- Verify generation runs
- Run again, say no
- Verify clean exit with helpful message

## Task
Enhance repo summarizer to detect monorepos and map packages.

## Implementation
- Check root package.json for workspaces field
- If workspaces found, scan for nested package.json files
- Build packages array with: path, name, main/exports
- Add to repo-summary.json

## Output Shape
packages: [{path, name, main, exports}, ...]
is_monorepo: boolean
workspace_root: string

## Acceptance Criteria
- Monorepos detected via workspaces field
- All nested packages discovered
- Package names extracted from each package.json

## Validation
- Run on chakra-ui fixture (known monorepo)
- Verify packages array populated
- Verify package names correct

## Task
Add new config fields for monorepo package targeting.

## Implementation
- Add to [inputs] section of superconnect.toml:
  - target_package: path to package dir (e.g. packages/design-system)
  - import_from: npm package name (e.g. @corp/design-system)
- import_from can be auto-inferred from target_package's package.json name
- Update TOML parsing and validation

## Acceptance Criteria
- New fields parsed from toml
- import_from defaults to package.json name if not specified
- Validation error if target_package does not exist

## Validation
- Create toml with target_package set
- Verify import_from auto-detected
- Verify error if path invalid

## Task
When init detects monorepo, show package picker.

## Implementation
- After scanning repo, if is_monorepo is true:
- Show list of discovered packages with component counts
- Let user pick which package is the design system
- Set target_package and import_from based on selection
- For single-package repos, skip picker

## UX
Found monorepo with 4 packages:
  1. @corp/design-system (packages/design-system) - 47 components
  2. @corp/icons (packages/icons) - 12 components
  3. @corp/utils (packages/utils) - 0 components
  4. docs (apps/docs) - private

Which package contains your design system? [1]

## Acceptance Criteria
- Monorepo triggers package picker
- Single repos skip picker
- Selection populates target_package and import_from

## Validation
- Run init on monorepo fixture
- Verify picker appears
- Verify selection sets correct config

## Task
When target_package is set, only scan that package for components.

## Implementation
- If target_package is set in config:
- Change component scanning root to target_package path
- Only find components under that directory
- Update component_source_files to be relative to target_package
- Adjust component root detection patterns

## Acceptance Criteria
- Scanning limited to target_package directory
- Components from other packages not included
- File paths still correct for orienter

## Validation
- Set target_package to packages/design-system
- Run summarizer
- Verify only design-system components found
- Verify app components NOT found

## Task
Ensure codegen uses import_from for import statements.

## Implementation
- Read import_from from config
- Pass to codegen prompts as the canonical import path
- Update prompt to use this instead of inferring from file paths
- Update orientation output to include importPath field

## Generated Code Should Be
import { Button } from '@corp/design-system';

## NOT
import { Button } from '../../packages/design-system/src/components/Button';

## Acceptance Criteria
- Generated Code Connect uses package name imports
- import_from value used consistently
- No file path imports in output

## Validation
- Set import_from to @corp/design-system
- Run codegen
- Verify generated imports use @corp/design-system

## Task
Ensure single-repo projects continue to work without extra config.

## Implementation
- If no target_package specified and not a monorepo:
- Scan from repo root as before
- Infer import_from from root package.json name
- No breaking changes to existing workflow

## Acceptance Criteria
- Existing single-repo projects work unchanged
- No new required config fields for simple case
- Import path inferred from root package.json

## Validation
- Run on react-sample fixture (single repo)
- Verify works without target_package config
- Verify imports use package name from root package.json

Users often forget to set the Figma access token. Error message is confusing when API call fails.

## Implementation
- At startup, check if FIGMA_ACCESS_TOKEN env var is set
- If not set, show clear error with instructions:
  - How to get a token from Figma
  - How to set as env var (export FIGMA_ACCESS_TOKEN=xxx)
  - Link to Figma docs for token generation
- Exit early with helpful message instead of cryptic API error

## Files to Modify
- scripts/run-pipeline.js - add token check early in pipeline

## Message Example
Error: FIGMA_ACCESS_TOKEN environment variable not set.

To get a Figma access token:
1. Go to Figma > Settings > Account > Personal access tokens
2. Generate a new token
3. Run: export FIGMA_ACCESS_TOKEN=your-token-here

## Acceptance Criteria
- Clear error when FIGMA_ACCESS_TOKEN missing
- Instructions for how to get and set token
- Tool exits before attempting any Figma API calls

## Validation
- Unset FIGMA_ACCESS_TOKEN, run tool, verify helpful message
- Set token, run tool, verify normal operation

Add TypeScript tooling with Node native execution
## Task
Set up TypeScript with Node's native TS execution (no compile step).

## Approach
Node 22.6+ supports --experimental-strip-types, Node 23+ has --experimental-transform-types.
Node 25 has these as stable. We require Node >= 22, so we can use native TS.

## Implementation
1. Add tsconfig.json with:
   - target: ES2022
   - module: NodeNext
   - moduleResolution: NodeNext
   - strict: true
   - allowJs: true (for incremental migration)
   - noEmit: true (no compile step)

2. Add @types/node as devDependency

3. Update package.json:
   - Remove any build scripts that compile TS
   - Ensure bin entry points to .ts files
   - Add type: module if not present

4. Test that `node --experimental-strip-types scripts/run-pipeline.ts` works

## Files to Create
- tsconfig.json

## Files to Modify  
- package.json - add @types/node, update scripts

## Acceptance Criteria
- tsconfig.json exists with strict mode
- Node can run .ts files directly
- No separate build/compile step needed
- Existing .js files still work (allowJs: true)

## Validation
- Create a test.ts file with type annotations
- Run with node --experimental-strip-types test.ts
- Verify types are stripped and code runs
